Right hand

The first step towards a good right hand is relaxation.

Shake off all tension in your hand and let it hang down.
Now, using the other hand, raise the back part of the bow (the frog) under the fingers, into the middle phalanx bone of the index. (black line on the picture)

Keep your muscles entirely relaxed, while you push the bow up until the back of your hand is parallel to the floor.

Tip: Relaxation is key to playing the violin!
All tension, anywhere in the body, will work against the natural resonance of the violin

Without tensing anything, put your thumb in between the wood and the hair of the bow, against the frog. This should leave your thumb under the middle and ring finger.

The final touch to our bowhold will be to put the little finger on top of the bow.
Both the thumb and the little finger should be nicely rounded,
forming a kind of broken circle if you look at them from the side.

Make sure to keep all fingers relaxed and round.
Just like when they were hanging down before, the fingers shouldn't touch, nor be too far apart.

If you let go of the bow with the left hand, you'll notice the little finger has to do a lot of work, but don't worry, when the bow is on the violin, the violin does a lot of this work for us!

Time to put the bow on the strings and make some sound!

Most of the time, we'll have the violin between the fingerboard and the bridge. For now, put the bow in about 1/3 of this distance, starting at the fingerboard: Around this place, it's easiest to make a nice sound.

Try moving the bow across one of the strings. Don't put any pressure on, the weight of the bow is plenty!
Look at the bow to make sure it stays parallel to the bridge, otherwise, the bow will move to the side.

Tip: Try playing on all 4 strings with each of the 4 fingers as well,
then you've already played about half of the notes you can play on a violin!
Thanks for reading this intro to the violin, and remember to practice!
